title: 110_s1276
content: The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 is cited as the short title. Amendments are made to the Controlled Substances Act regarding signature capture and retention for electronic methamphetamine precursor logbook systems. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 amends the Controlled Substances Act to require purchasers of methamphetamine precursors to present an identification card issued by the government and sign a logbook with their name, address, and purchase details. Electronic logbooks may capture signatures using specific devices. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 requires purchasers of methamphetamine precursors to sign a logbook with their details. Electronic devices can capture signatures and link them to purchaser information. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 mandates purchasers of methamphetamine precursors to sign a logbook with their details, including product names, quantities, purchaser's name and address, and sale date and time. The logbook can be in the form of a bound paper book with a unique identifier or a printed document signed by the purchaser at the time of sale. The seller must print a document at the time of sale containing the purchaser's details, signature line, and a notice. The signed document should be stored securely after the purchaser signs it. The seller records product details and sales quantity in a logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook also includes the purchaser's name, address, and sale date and time. The seller must verify purchaser information entered in the logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook includes a notice about the consequences of providing false information. The seller must maintain logbook entries for at least 2 years, and providing false information may lead to criminal penalties under section 1001 of title 18, United States Code.
